title: Sports in Puerto Rico
text:
Sports in Puerto Rico can be traced from the ceremonial competitions amongst the <a href="pre-Columbian">pre-Columbian</a> Native Americans of the Arawak (<a href="Ta%C3%ADno%20people">Taíno</a>) tribes who inhabited the island to the modern era in which sports activities consist of an organized physical activity or skill carried out with a recreational purpose for competition. One of the sports which the Taíno's played was a ball game called "Batey". The "Batey" was played in "U" shaped fields two teams; however, unlike the ball games of the modern era, the winners were treated like heroes and the losers were sacrificed.
The Spanish Conquistadores who conquered the island introduced various sports such as <a href="horse%20racing">horse racing</a>, <a href="cockfighting">cockfighting</a>, <a href="dominoes">dominoes</a> and a game similar to "Bowling" called "Boliche". The Spaniards however did not participate in team sports.
Spain ceded Puerto Rico to the United States as a result of their defeat in the 1898 <a href="Spanish%E2%80%93American%20War">Spanish–American War</a>. American soldiers who organized games as part of their training introduced the sport of Boxing and Basketball to the people of Puerto Rico. The sport of baseball, which was invented in the United States, was introduced to the island by a group of Puerto Ricans and Cubans who learned the sport in the United States.
Puerto Rico participates in the Olympics as an independent nation even though it is a territory of the United States. Puerto Rico has participated as such since the 1948 Summer Olympics celebrated in London. On March 2, 1917, Puerto Ricans became citizens of the United States as a result of the enactment of the <a href="Jones%E2%80%93Shafroth%20Act">Jones–Shafroth Act</a> (Pub.L. 64–368, 39 Stat. 951) and as such Puerto Ricans who resided in the United States mainland were and still are permitted to participate and represent that country in international sports events. However, their achievements representing the United States is part of the intertwined history of sports in the United States and Puerto Rico.
The following is the list and history of the most common sports practiced in Puerto Rico and other countries and of the Puerto Ricans or people of Puerto Rican descent who have excelled in those sports locally and/or in international events as representatives of Puerto Rico or any other country.
Brief history of sports in Puerto Rico.
Pre-Columbian era.
The Taínos who inhabited Puerto Rico before the arrival of <a href="Christopher%20Columbus">Christopher Columbus</a> in 1492, played a series of games which were both ceremonial and diversional, such as races, contests involving body strength and fishing. However, the two most important of these sports were the simulated warrior fights (similar to the gladiators) and ball playing. The ball game was played in a field, which they called "Batey", situated in the middle of the village. The fields were either shaped like a triangle or like a "U". The ball was made of vegetable leaves, which gave it flexibility. Two teams played against each other. The objective of the game was to keep the ball in constant motion. The players were allowed to use their heads, elbows, shoulders and knees. The team would lose a point, if for any reason the ball stopped moving. The score was kept with a mark on the ground and the game would end after the losing team received a certain number of points. The winners were treated like heroes and the losers were sacrificed. The game had changed by the time the first Spanish settlers arrived. According to Fray <a href="Bartolom%C3%A9%20de%20las%20Casas">Bartolomé de las Casas</a> the game was played in the following manner: "One team served the ball and the other team returned it, using anything but the hands. If the ball arrived at shoulder height, it was returned like lightning. When it came in near the ground, the player rapidly hit the ground, striking the ball with his buttocks. Play continued from side to side until an error was made." In 1975, archaeologists from the Guaynia Society of Archeology and History at the Catholic University of Puerto Rico, members of the Archeological Society of the Southwest announced the discovery of the ruins of a "Batey" in an area called Tibes, on the outskirts of the city of <a href="Ponce%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">Ponce</a>. A total of 9 ball fields were discovered under thick forest overgrowth dating back to AD 25 in the area which is now known as "<a href="Centro%20Ceremonial%20Indigena%20de%20Tibes">Centro Ceremonial Indigena de Tibes</a>" (The Tibes Indigenoius Ceremonial Center). The site is now a tourist attraction and is open to the public. Artifacts found on the site are on display and can be seen in a museum on the site and in the Ponce Museum of Art.
Spanish colonization.
The first Spaniards to inhabit the island were soldiers (Conquistadores), later they were followed by farmers, miners and their families. Team sports were virtually unheard of however, there were other types of competitions and sports in which they participated. The most common sports were <a href="horse%20racing">horse racing</a>, <a href="cockfighting">cockfighting</a> and <a href="dominoes">dominoes</a>. The first horse track was built in San Juan in 1887. One of the most popular sports was "Boliche". The men would gather in the town plaza and roll a small ball made of wood with the objective of knocking down pins. "Boliche" was similar to <a href="bowling">bowling</a>. Another popular sport was <a href="bullfighting">bullfighting</a>, which was limited to the larger cities of <a href="Ponce%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">Ponce</a> and <a href="San%20Juan%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">San Juan</a>.
American (United States) colonization.
In the late 19th century "new" sports were introduced in Puerto Rico, after Puerto Rico became an American territory when the United States defeated Spain in the <a href="Spanish%E2%80%93American%20War">Spanish–American War</a>. Baseball, which was invented in the United States, was introduced to the island by a group of Puerto Ricans and Cubans who learned the sport in the United States. The sport was also played by the American soldiers who organized games as part of their training. Puerto Ricans were also introduced to the sports of boxing and basketball by the occupying military forces.
Modern era.
Puerto Rico and Puerto Ricans in the Olympic Games.
Puerto Rico participates in the Olympics as an independent nation but because of Puerto Ricans having American citizenship, Puerto Rican athletes have the option of representing Puerto Rico or moving to the United States, living there for 3 previous years or more and then representing that country in the games. Some Puerto Ricans, such as Gigi Fernández in tennis, have won gold medals for the U.S.
The <a href="1948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948 Summer Olympics</a> celebrated in London, was a historical one for Puerto Rico because it was the first time that the island would participate as a nation in a major international sporting event. The island's delegation consisted of only three members, two of which finished among the ten best in <a href="pole%20vault">pole vault</a>. In their regional participations, the Puerto Ricans had carried the United States flag into the games. The United States protested, claiming that two nations could not use the same flag at the same time. The decree of <a href="Commonwealth%20%28U.S.%20insular%20area%29">Commonwealth</a> on July 25, 1952 would give the Puerto Rican delegation a flag of their own.
In 1980, the United States boycotted the Olympic Games in Moscow, Russian SFSR, USSR in protest of the <a href="Soviet%20invasion%20of%20Afghanistan">Soviet invasion of Afghanistan</a>. <a href="Germ%C3%A1n%20Rieckehoff">Germán Rieckehoff</a>, who was then the president of the Puerto Rican Olympic Committee, was against the boycott because he believed that politics should not get involved with sporting events. He was, therefore, denied economic support from the local government. Rieckehoff did however, manage to send one athlete to represent Puerto Rico in <a href="boxing">boxing</a>, <a href="Alberto%20Mercado">Alberto Mercado</a>, who became the only American citizen to participate in the 1980 Olympics.
In 1982, the Government of Puerto Rico, headed by then governor <a href="Carlos%20Romero%20Barcel%C3%B3">Carlos Romero Barceló</a>, withheld economic support from the athletic delegation headed to <a href="Cuba">Cuba</a>, where the Central American and Caribbean Games were going to be held. The Puerto Rican Olympic Committee, under the leadership of Rieckehoff, had to appeal directly to the people for donations and were able to send the delegation. The Puerto Rican Olympic Committee is also the organization in charge of selecting the Puerto Rican athletes which represent the island in the <a href="Pan%20American%20Games">Pan American Games</a> and the Central American and Caribbean Games.
The <a href="Puerto%20Rico%20national%20baseball%20team">Puerto Rican national baseball team</a> won a bronze medal at the <a href="1988%20Summer%20Olympic%20Games">1988 Summer Olympic Games</a> in Seoul, South Korea, but that medal is not counted among Puerto Rico's Olympic medals totals because baseball was only an exhibition sport during those games.
The <a href="1988%20Winter%20Olympics">1988 Winter Olympics</a>, officially known as the "XV Olympic Winter Games", was celebrated in <a href="Calgary">Calgary</a>, <a href="Alberta">Alberta</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a> between February 13 and 28. It was the first Winter Olympics ever held in Canada. It was also the first time that a Puerto Rican team was sent to represent the island in an Olympic ski competition. No Puerto Rican had ever skied in the Olympics. The six-person Puerto Rican ski team was made up of native Puerto Ricans. They were <a href="F%C3%A9lix%20Flechas">Félix Flechas</a>, <a href="Walter%20Sandza">Walter Sandza</a>, <a href="Kevin%20Wilson%20%28skier%29">Kevin Wilson</a>, his sister <a href="Mary%20Pat%20Wilson">Mary Pat Wilson</a> and <a href="Jason%20Edelmann">Jason Edelmann</a>. Mary Pat Wilson is Puerto Rico's first and only female Olympic skier. Even though the team did not do well in the competition, they were highly respected by their competitors. Since then. Puerto Rico has participated in all but three of the Winter Olympic Games, missing those of 2006, 2010, and 2014.
<a href="Kristina%20Brandi">Kristina Brandi</a> represented Puerto Rico in the <a href="2004%20Summer%20Olympics">2004 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Athens%2C%20Greece">Athens, Greece</a>. She became the first tennis player representing Puerto Rico to win a singles match in an Olympic when she beat <a href="Jelena%20Kostani%C4%87">Jelena Kostanić</a> from <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a> (7–5 and 6–1). She lost in the second round to Russian <a href="Anastasia%20Myskina">Anastasia Myskina</a>.
At the <a href="2016%20Summer%20Olympics">2016 Summer Olympics</a> in Rio de Janeiro, <a href="Monica%20Puig">Monica Puig</a> made Olympic history when she became the first person to win an Olympic gold medal for Puerto Rico by defeating Germany's <a href="Angelique%20Kerber">Angelique Kerber</a> in the <a href="Tennis%20at%20the%202016%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20singles">women's singles tennis</a> final. She became the first Puerto Rican female medalist in any sport. On August 2, 2021, <a href="Jasmine%20Camacho-Quinn">Jasmine Camacho-Quinn</a> won Puerto Rico's second Olympic Gold Medal. She won the medal in the Women's 100m Hurdles in the Olympic games which were celebrated in Tokyo, Japan.
Olympics medallists.
The following table has a list of Puerto Ricans, including people of Puerto Rican ancestry, who won Olympic medals. "Puerto Ricans" is a term also used to describe a resident of the United States who was "born in Puerto Rico or who traces their family ancestry to Puerto Rico." Not all represented the island, some represented the United States. Puerto Ricans have won a total of 38 Olympic medals, 28 representing the United States and 10 representing Puerto Rico. 
Puerto Rico at the Paralympic Games.
Puerto Rico debuted in the <a href="Paralympic%20Games">Paralympic Games</a> on <a href="1988%20Summer%20Paralympics">1988</a>. In this event, <a href="Isabel%20Bustamante">Isabel Bustamante</a> was awarded the first medals for the delegation, winning one gold and two silver medals in athletics. In the <a href="2000%20Summer%20Paralympics">2000 Summer Paralympics</a>, Alexis Pizarro became the first male athlete to win a medal for Puerto Rico, reaching bronze in athletics. Pizarro repeated this performance in the <a href="2004%20Summer%20Paralympics">2004 Summer Paralympics</a>.
On August 20, 2008, <a href="David%20Bernier">David Bernier</a> awarded the flag of Puerto Rico to Nilda Gómez, who was selected to be the flag bearer in the opening ceremonies of the <a href="2008%20Paralympics">2008 Paralympics</a>. Three athletes that registered A-marks attended the ceremony, which also included Alexis Pizarro in athletics and Julio Reguero in sailing. Puerto Rico's first medal in this edition of the Paralympics was won by Gómez, who won bronze in <a href="Shooting%20sports">rifle shooting</a>. She won bronze in the 10-meter trial, finishing with 489 points.
Puerto Rico at the Special Olympics.
Puerto Rico's Special Olympics program was founded in 1970, since then it has offered services to more than a thousand athletes.
In the <a href="2003%20Special%20Olympics%20World%20Summer%20Games">2003 Special Olympics World Summer Games</a>, Puerto Rico won 57 medals.
Puerto Rico won a total of 34 medals in the <a href="2007%20Special%20Olympics%20World%20Summer%20Games">2007 Special Olympics World Summer Games</a>, including 7 gold, 18 silver and 9 bronze medals. Due to the team's performance, the <a href="Senate%20of%20Puerto%20Rico">Senate of Puerto Rico</a> organized a ceremony where the athletes and trainers received recognitions.
Distribution and practice among sports.
American football.
<a href="Ron%20Rivera">Ron Rivera</a> became the first <a href="National%20Football%20League">NFL</a> player of Puerto Rican descent when he played for the <a href="Chicago%20Bears">Chicago Bears</a> in the 1980s. In 1986, Rivera also became the first NFL player of Puerto Rican descent to win a <a href="Super%20Bowl">Super Bowl</a> championship ring.
Others who have played in the NFL are <a href="O.J.%20Santiago">O.J. Santiago</a> of the <a href="Atlanta%20Falcons">Atlanta Falcons</a>, <a href="Marco%20Rivera">Marco Rivera</a> who played for the <a href="Dallas%20Cowboys">Dallas Cowboys</a> and who in 2002 became the first Puerto Rican to play in the <a href="Pro%20Bowl">Pro Bowl</a> as a member of the <a href="Green%20Bay%20Packers">Green Bay Packers</a> (the first of three appearances) and <a href="Glenn%20Martinez">Glenn Martinez</a> who in 2005 played for the <a href="Detroit%20Lions">Detroit Lions</a>, <a href="Ken%20Amato">Ken Amato</a> who played for the <a href="Tennessee%20Titans">Tennessee Titans</a> and <a href="Alvin%20Pearman">Alvin Pearman</a> who played with the <a href="Jacksonville%20Jaguars">Jacksonville Jaguars</a> are of Puerto Rican descent. <a href="Willie%20Colon%20%28American%20football%29">Willie Colon</a> who was drafted by the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> in 2006 and won <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLIII">Super Bowl XLIII</a> is also of Puerto Rican descent. <a href="Aaron%20Hernandez">Aaron Hernandez</a>, formerly of the <a href="New%20England%20Patriots">New England Patriots</a>, was also of Puerto Rican descent. <a href="Victor%20Cruz%20%28American%20football%29">Victor Cruz</a>, another player of Puerto Rican descent, played for the <a href="New%20York%20Giants">New York Giants</a> and was known for his salsa touchdown dance. While all of these players are of Puerto Rican descent, there has yet to be a Puerto Rican born NFL player.
American Football has been played in the island for many decades, dating all the way back to the installment of American military bases. Puerto Rico currently has 4 football leagues. PR Pee Wee league, for children 8-16, PRHSFL, for high school students, the newly created AFAF, for college students, and PRAFL, a semi-professional league. Although football has been in the island for so many years, it is not widely known. Many things attribute to this, for example lack of proper funding and advertising, lack of high school affiliated teams, both attributing to lack of good coaching. In July 2012, the Puerto Rico American Football Federation became a member of the <a href="International%20Federation%20of%20American%20Football">International Federation of American Football</a>.
Pee Wee Football League
This federation has 4 divisions, with areas in: Baldrich, Parque Central, University Gardens, Parkville, Ft. Buchanan, Carolina, and lastly Caguas. The league is played from January to March at "El Complejo Deportivo Roberto Clemente" in San Juan Saturday mornings. The following is a table with the years and weight distribution for each division:
PRHSFL
This league has 6 Varsity teams and 3 teams at Junior Varsity level. the league is made up of 2 schools, Antilles High School Pirates, and Commonwealth Comets, and four clubs, Carolina Blittz, Bayamón Wolfpack, University Garden Dolphins, and Parque Central Blue Wave.
AFAF
This league was founded in 2009 to rival the PRAFL and to one day be a part of local college athletics. There are four teams, Cataño Gators, San Juan Hurricanes, Carolina Blittz, and Baldrige Falcons.
PRAFL (<a href="Puerto%20Rico%20American%20Football%20League">Puerto Rico American Football League</a>)
A semi-professional league founded in 1985, with 5 teams. The Bayamón Wolfpack, Baldrich 57 Falcons, Carolina Blitzz, Cataño Lancheros, and Fajardo Cariduros.
The Cataño Lancheros were the 2011 PRAFL Champions.
Baseball.
Early history of baseball in Puerto Rico.
During the late 19th century Puerto Rico was to witness the introduction of organized team sports. The game of <a href="baseball">baseball</a> was first introduced to the island by a group of Puerto Ricans and Cubans who had learned the game in the United States. At first the sport was not well received by the local press and general public, it was looked upon as a silly game. The first two baseball clubs were founded in 1897. They were the Almendares Baseball Club, owned by Francisco Alamo Armas and the Borinquen Baseball Club owned by Santos Filippi.
According to the daily newspaper "El País", on January 11, 1898, the first organized baseball game was played in Puerto Rico at the old velodrome which was located at the Pda.15 in Santurce, San Juan. The Borinquen team beat the Almendares with a score of 3 to 0. The first game to go a complete nine innings was played on January 30, 1898 and the Borinquen once again beat the Almendares with a score of 9 to 3.
Puerto Rico became an American territory when the United States defeated Spain in the <a href="Spanish%E2%80%93American%20War">Spanish–American War</a>. The American soldiers stationed in Puerto Rico were permitted to organize a baseball club to play against the local clubs as diversional outlet. On November 4, 1900 the Almendares Baseball Club composed of Puerto Ricans and Cubans beat the American Baseball Club of the Second Regiment of Infantry with a score of 32 to 18. In the early 1920s, teams from Puerto Rico, such as the San Juan Stars, would travel to New York City and play against some of teams there which included teams made up of Puerto Ricans who lived there.
Modern era
Puerto Rico has over 100 <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> players who are currently active, in addition to the hundreds others who have participated in the past. These facts combine to make baseball one of the most popular sports in the island.
Some of the most notable baseball players from Puerto Rico are five Hall of Famers <a href="Roberto%20Clemente">Roberto Clemente</a>, <a href="Orlando%20Cepeda">Orlando Cepeda</a>, <a href="Roberto%20Alomar">Roberto Alomar</a>, <a href="Iv%C3%A1n%20Rodr%C3%ADguez">Iván "Pudge" Rodríguez</a> and <a href="Edgar%20Martinez">Edgar Martinez</a>. Another baseball player who is a Hall of Famer and who was born to a Puerto Rican father is <a href="Reggie%20Jackson">Reginald Martinez "Reggie" Jackson</a>. Also amongst the notable players or former players are <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Cruz">Jose "Cheo" Cruz</a>, <a href="Juan%20Gonz%C3%A1lez%20%28baseball%20player%29">Juan González</a>, <a href="Victor%20Pellot">Victor Pellot</a>, <a href="Jorge%20Posada">Jorge Posada</a> and <a href="Bernie%20Williams">Bernie Williams</a>.
Chronological order of major events
Currently.
Puerto Rico has a winter baseball league named the <a href="Puerto%20Rico%20Baseball%20League">Puerto Rico Baseball League</a> that has operated since the early 20th century. The champion of the Puerto Rico league represents Puerto Rico is in the annual <a href="Caribbean%20World%20Series">Caribbean World Series</a>. It currently has six teams:
The <a href="Puerto%20Rico%20national%20baseball%20team">Puerto Rico national baseball team</a> competes in international events, including the <a href="World%20Baseball%20Classic">World Baseball Classic</a>, separately from the United States. <a href="Hiram%20Bithorn%20Stadium">Hiram Bithorn Stadium</a> in San Juan has hosted first-round games in each of the first three World Baseball Classic tournaments.
Basketball.
Early history of basketball in Puerto Rico.
The United States military government banned cockfighting and bullfighting from the island. They did, however, introduce a "new" sport called basketball. Basketball was used by the American soldiers as part of their physical training. When the soldiers played basketball, they used a plain straw basket which was cut open at both ends and placed it on the highest end of a pole. For a ball, they used a football and the game was played without any established set of rules.
In 1913, the <a href="YMCA">YMCA</a> of Puerto Rico organized the first game played using the official rules of basketball and in 1916, the YMCA organized the first basketball tournament in Puerto Rico. Teams organized in the other YMCAs in the island participated in the tournament. The first basketball organization in Puerto Rico was the San Juan Basketball League. <a href="R%C3%ADo%20Piedras%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">Río Piedras</a> and <a href="Bayam%C3%B3n%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">Bayamón</a> later followed and formed their own leagues.
Basketball became a popular sport in Puerto Rico, due in part to the <a href="National%20Superior%20Basketball">BSN</a>, which has been around since the 1930s. During the early 1980s, with many games shown on television, the sport's popularity increased. There is also a women's professional league, which is affiliated to the BSN. <a href="Street%20basketball">Street basketball</a> is also popular among Puerto Rico's youth.
Chronological order of major events
International Puerto Rican Basketball players.
<a href="Puerto%20Rican%20national%20basketball%20team">Puerto Rico's national basketball team</a> has reached the Olympic Games multiple times, including the <a href="2004%20Athens%20Olympics">2004 Athens Olympics</a>, where they became the first team to defeat the United States <a href="Dream%20Team%20%28basketball%29">Dream Team</a> during Olympic competition. Puerto Rico's national team has won gold medals in other international competitions.
Puerto Ricans have also been members of the <a href="Harlem%20Globetrotters">Harlem Globetrotters</a>. In 1995, <a href="Orlando%20Antigua">Orlando Antigua</a>, whose mother is Puerto Rican, became the first non-black in 52 years to play for the <a href="Harlem%20Globetrotters">Harlem Globetrotters</a>. In 2008, <a href="Orlando%20Melendez">Orlando Melendez</a> a.k.a. "El Gato" became the first Puerto Rican-born player and the second Hispanic to play for the Harlem Globetrotters.
Bobsled.
Puerto Rico had a Bobsled team in the 1992, 1994 and 1998 <a href="Winter%20Olympics">Winter Olympics</a>.
Boxing.
Early history of boxing in Puerto Rico.
The sport of <a href="boxing">boxing</a> was also introduced by the United States military which occupied Puerto Rico and the same as Basketball, boxing was used by the American soldiers as part of their physical training. Boxing competitions amongst the soldiers were open to the public. The first boxing match in Puerto Rico was held on January 15, 1899.
Boxing has, for many years, disputed the top spot for the Puerto Rican fan's favorite sport with Baseball and Basketball. Puerto Ricans have distinguished themselves both as amateurs and professionals. In 1917, <a href="Nero%20Chen">Nero Chen</a> became the first Puerto Rican professional boxer to gain international recognition. Puerto Rico has also been the site of many championship fights.
Boxing in the Olympics.
In 1948, boxer <a href="Juan%20Evangelista%20Venegas">Juan Evangelista Venegas</a> earned Puerto Rico's first Olympic medal, finishing his participation in London with a bronze medal that year. Subsequently, Puerto Rico has earned five more medals in Olympic boxing, including a silver one by <a href="Luis%20Ortiz%20%28Puerto%20Rican%20boxer%29">Luis Ortiz</a> in 1984. That silver medal is the only silver medal ever won by any Puerto Rican native at Olympic Games. Although he did not win a medal, <a href="Alberto%20Mercado">Alberto Mercado</a> became, in 1980, the only American citizen to actually participate in the <a href="Moscow%20Olympics">Moscow Olympics</a>.
Professional boxing.
There are thirteen Puerto Ricans in the <a href="International%20Boxing%20Hall%20of%20Fame">International Boxing Hall of Fame</a>, they are Puerto Rico's first world champion <a href="Sixto%20Escobar">Sixto Escobar</a>, <a href="Wilfred%20Ben%C3%ADtez">Wilfred Benítez</a>, <a href="Wilfredo%20G%C3%B3mez">Wilfredo Gómez</a>, <a href="Carlos%20Ort%C3%ADz">Carlos Ortíz</a>, <a href="Edwin%20Rosario">Edwin Rosario</a>, <a href="Pedro%20Monta%C3%B1ez">Pedro Montañez</a>, <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Torres">José Chegui Torres</a>, <a href="Joe%20Cortez">Joe Cortez</a> (referee), <a href="Herbert%20Lewis%20Hardwick">Herbert "Cocoa Kid" Hardwick</a>, <a href="F%C3%A9lix%20Trinidad">Felix "Tito" Trinidad</a>, <a href="Hector%20Camacho">Hector "Macho" Camacho</a>, <a href="Mario%20Rivera%20Martino">Mario Rivera Martino</a> (writer) and <a href="Miguel%20Cotto">Miguel Cotto</a>. Benítez (The youngest champion in boxing's history) as of May 23, 1981, was the youngest three-time world champion after knocking out World Junior Middleweight champion <a href="Maurice%20Hope">Maurice Hope</a>. Hardwick, was a member of the feared "<a href="Murderers%27%20Row">Black Murderers' Row</a>". The late Mario Rivera Martino, served Puerto Rican boxing for more than 50 years as a writer and eventual commissioner.
Other boxers from Puerto Rico which have excelled in the sport include: <a href="Carlos%20De%20Leon">Carlos De Leon</a>, <a href="Ossie%20Ocasio">Ossie Ocasio</a>, <a href="Alfredo%20Escalera">Alfredo Escalera</a>, <a href="Belinda%20Laracuente">Belinda Laracuente</a>, <a href="John%20Ruiz">John Ruiz</a> who made history by becoming boxing's first Latin American world Heavyweight champion ever, after beating <a href="World%20Boxing%20Association">WBA</a> world champ <a href="Evander%20Holyfield">Evander Holyfield</a>, <a href="Alex%20S%C3%A1nchez%20%28boxer%29">Alex Sánchez</a>, <a href="Samuel%20Serrano">Samuel</a> and <a href="Amanda%20Serrano">Amanda Serrano</a> (no relation), <a href="Ada%20V%C3%A9lez">Ada Vélez</a>, who is the first Puerto Rican <a href="Women%27s%20boxing">Women's boxing</a> world champion and <a href="Jose%20Miguel%20Cotto">Jose Miguel Cotto</a>.
In 2006, Puerto Rican <a href="Miguel%20Santana">Miguel Santana</a> made boxing history by becoming the fighter who waited the longest after a title bout to have a losing world title bout recognized as a mistake by a major organization. The IBF recognized Santana's challenge of IBF Lightweight champion <a href="Greg%20Haugen">Greg Haugen</a> (who originally beat Santana by an eleventh round technical decision) as erroneous because of a fight-fixing and betting scandal that took place during the era the contest happened, and gave Santana a special recognition.
Chronological order of major events
Among the international boxers who fought in Puerto Rico in a title bout are <a href="Muhammad%20Ali">Muhammad Ali</a>, <a href="Roberto%20Dur%C3%A1n">Roberto Durán</a>, and <a href="Alexis%20Arg%C3%BCello">Alexis Argüello</a>. The 1970s became known in Puerto Rico as "the golden era of Borinquen's (Puerto Rico's) Boxing".
Cockfights.
Unlike in most states of the United States, <a href="cockfighting">cockfighting</a> was legal in Puerto Rico until 2018, and there are many places that draw large crowds to see bantams fighting every weekend. It is known as the Gentleman's Sport due to the common practice of wagers being a verbal contract between two individuals and may range from $1 to thousands of dollars. Across the world, Puerto Rico has been seen as the largest capital for the controversial sport, as it is incredibly popular and often televised as other sports are. <a href="Rooster">Rooster</a>s are specially bred to fight, first entering the ring between one and two years of age.
In 2018, the United States announced that it would ban cockfights in all its territories, including Puerto Rico. The ban began in January 2019.
Equestrian.
The sport of equestrianism has certain popularity in Puerto Rico, more so among members of higher classes. Puerto Rico frequently sends contestants to different international tournaments, such as the Olympics. On August 16, 2003, <a href="Mark%20Watring">Mark Watring</a>l from the town of Aguadilla, represented the United States in the <a href="Pan%20American%20Games">Pan American Games</a> celebrated in the <a href="Dominican%20Republic">Dominican Republic</a>. There he won the "Gold Medal" with a final total of 13.66 penalties compared to the 21.87 posted by Mexico. When presented with the Gold Medal, Watring unfurled and waved the <a href="Puerto%20Rican%20Flag">Puerto Rican Flag</a>. This win secured a berth in the <a href="2004%20Olympic%20Game">2004 Olympic Game</a>s in <a href="Athens">Athens</a>, Greece. Watring represented Puerto Rico in the 2004 Olympics.
Fencing.
Fencing in Puerto Rico has become popular ever since <a href="David%20%26quot%3BKike%26quot%3B%20Bernier">David "Kike" Bernier</a>, Victor Bernier and the brothers Jonathan and Marcos Peña have won medals in the 2003 <a href="Pan%20American%20Games">Pan American Games</a> celebrated in the <a href="Dominican%20Republic">Dominican Republic</a>.Mirthescka Escanellas was also a popular Puerto Rican fencer. She participated at the <a href="1996%20Summer%20Olympics">1996 Summer Olympics</a> in <a href="Atlanta%2C%20Georgia">Atlanta, Georgia</a>, among many other international events.
Golf.
While <a href="golf">golf</a> is not very popular in Puerto Rico, there are many golf courses across the island such as the one at <a href="Club%20Deportivo%20del%20Oeste">Club Deportivo del Oeste</a>. The most famous Puerto Rican golfer is <a href="Juan%20%26quot%3BChi-Chi%26quot%3B%20Rodr%C3%ADguez">Juan "Chi-Chi" Rodríguez</a> who was inducted into the <a href="World%20Golf%20Hall%20of%20Fame">World Golf Hall of Fame</a> in 1992. Rodríguez used to put his hat over the hole whenever he made a <a href="Golf%20glossary">birdie</a> or <a href="Golf%20glossary">eagle</a>. After he heard that other golfers were complaining about his little act, he decided to try something new. Rodríguez developed his signature "<a href="Torero%20%28bullfighter%29">toreador</a> dance", where he would make believe that the birdie was a "bull" and that his <a href="Golf%20club%20%28equipment%29%23Club%20types">putter</a> was a "sword" and he would terminate the "bull". Rodríguez represented Puerto Rico on 12 <a href="World%20Cup%20%28men%27s%20golf%29">World Cup</a> teams. In 1986, he won the <a href="Hispanic">Hispanic</a> Recognition Award. In 1988, he was named "Replica's Hispanic Man of the Year".
Horse racing.
Horse Racing is a sport which was first introduced to Puerto Rico by the Conquistadores. Horse Races continue to be a very popular sport in Puerto Rico til this day. During the earlier part of the 20th. century, races were held at El Comandante race track. Since 1972, "<a href="El%20Nuevo%20Comandante">El Nuevo Comandante</a>" now called "Hipodromo Camarero", in <a href="Can%C3%B3vanas%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">Canóvanas</a>, has been the home of Puerto Rico's Sunday horse races, and of the annual "<a href="Clasico%20del%20Caribe">Clasico del Caribe</a>", a race that reunites important horses from many countries.
Notable jockeys include <a href="Miguel%20Rivera%20%28jockey%29">Miguel A. Rivera</a>, who won the <a href="1974%20Preakness%20Stakes">1974 Preakness Stakes</a> and <a href="Belmont%20Stakes">1974 Belmont Stakes</a> aboard <a href="Little%20Current">Little Current</a>, and <a href="National%20Museum%20of%20Racing%20and%20Hall%20of%20Fame">U.S. Racing Hall of Fame</a> member, <a href="Angel%20Cordero%2C%20Jr.">Angel Cordero, Jr.</a> Cordero is one of the leading <a href="thoroughbred">thoroughbred</a> <a href="horse%20racing">horse racing</a> <a href="jockey">jockey</a>s of all time in terms of wins. He was the first and only Puerto Rican jockey to win all three of the <a href="American%20Classic%20Races">American Classic Races</a> which consist of the <a href="Kentucky%20Derby">Kentucky Derby</a>, <a href="Preakness%20Stakes">Preakness Stakes</a> and the <a href="Belmont%20Stakes">Belmont Stakes</a>. Two of the most famous horses in Puerto Rican history were <a href="Camarero">Camarero</a>, a world record holder for consecutive wins, and <a href="1976%20Kentucky%20Derby">1976 Kentucky Derby</a> winner, <a href="Bold%20Forbes">Bold Forbes</a>.
Road running.
<a href="Road%20running">Road running</a> have long been a part of Puerto Rico's sporting tradition. Many important races are run annually in the island, including the "Maraton de San Blas" in <a href="Coamo%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">Coamo</a>, long considered one of the most important <a href="half%20marathon">half marathon</a> races in the world, and the <a href="Ponce%20Marathon">Ponce Marathon</a>.
The <a href="World%27s%20Best%2010K">World's Best 10K</a> (WB10K), also known as "Maratón Teodoro Moscoso", is a <a href="10K%20run">10K run</a> celebrated in <a href="San%20Juan%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">San Juan, Puerto Rico</a> every year. It is certified by the <a href="Association%20of%20International%20Marathons%20and%20Road%20Races">Association of International Marathons and Road Races</a> (AIMS) and by the <a href="International%20Amateur%20Athletic%20Federation">International Amateur Athletic Federation</a> (IAAF). The event was also the first race transmitted live through the Internet, with audio, video and results. WB10K was ranked among the 20 most competitive races in the world. Notable marathon runners include: <a href="Jorge%20Gonz%C3%A1lez%20%28athlete%29">Jorge "Peco" González</a> and Hunga Maldonado.
Martial arts.
Martial arts sports, especially <a href="karate">karate</a>, have had a marked ascent in popularity in Puerto Rico since the 1970s, when <a href="Bruce%20Lee">Bruce Lee</a> and <a href="Jackie%20Chan">Jackie Chan</a> movies were very popular among Puerto Rico's youth.
Olympic-style wrestling.
<a href="Jaime%20Espinal">Jaime Espinal</a> won a silver medal for Puerto Rico at the 84 kg Men's freestyle category at the <a href="2012%20Summer%20Olympics">2012 Summer Olympics</a> in London, earning Puerto Rico its second ever silver medal at the Olympics, its first since boxer Luis Ortiz in 1984, and its first Olympic medal in wrestling.
Professional wrestling.
Professional wrestling has enjoyed much popularity in Puerto Rico for a long time. Matches have been televised since the 1960s, and multiple, non televised matches are held each week across the island. <a href="World%20Wrestling%20Council">World Wrestling Council</a> is the main wrestling promoter in Puerto Rico.
Famous Puerto Rican wrestlers have included Barrabas, <a href="Carlos%20Col%C3%B3n%2C%20Sr.">Carlos Colón</a> and his sons, <a href="Carlito%20Col%C3%B3n">Carlito</a> and <a href="Primo%20Colon">Primo Colon</a>, "Los Invaders", <a href="Savio%20Vega">Savio Vega</a>, WWF* Hall of Famer <a href="Pedro%20Morales">Pedro Morales</a>, and "Los Super Medicos". In addition, many <a href="World%20Wrestling%20Entertainment">World Wrestling Entertainment</a> (WWE, formerly WWF) stars, such as <a href="Randy%20Savage">Randy Savage</a>, and <a href="Ric%20Flair">Ric Flair</a> fought in Puerto Rico before. Women's wrestling has been gaining popularity in Puerto Rico since the 1990s with performers like La Tigresa, and Black Rose.
Two Puerto Ricans have been inducted into the WWE Hall of Fame. They are Pedro Morales (1995) and Carlos Colon (2014).
Sailing.
Sailing as a sport has picked up in popularity in Puerto Rico since the middle 1990s, under the leadership of <a href="Enrique%20Figueroa">Enrique Figueroa</a> and his wife, <a href="Carla%20Malatrasi">Carla Malatrasi</a>. The pair have combined to win many international medals, and they competed at the <a href="2000%20Olympic%20Games">2000 Olympic Games</a>. Figueroa also participated at the <a href="1992%20Summer%20Olympics">1992 Olympics</a>. On February 2, 2004, Figueroa and teammate Jorge Hernández, won the Olympic Games Rolex Regatta. They were named champions by topping 29 entries in the tornado fleet. The <a href="regatta">regatta</a> winners had their sights set on the <a href="2004%20Olympic%20Games">2004 Olympics</a> and Paralympic Games in <a href="Athens">Athens</a>, Greece. 503 sailors participated with a fleet of 323 boats representing 39 nations. Figueroa went to the 2004 Olympic Games and represented Puerto Rico.
Fútbol (Soccer).
The sport known as "soccer" in the United States, is also known and referred to as "Fútbol" or in the Spanish language as "balompié". 
Puerto Rico has a Puerto Rico Soccer League which is sponsored by the Federación Puertorriqueña de Fútbol. Fútbol, unlike in many of the other Latin American countries, mainly because of the strong American culture influence on the Island, did not enjoy high popularity during the 20th century. But since the new millennium it has slowly increased its fan base on the island. <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a> has a <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a> sponsored federation, the <a href="Federaci%C3%B3n%20Puertorrique%C3%B1a%20de%20F%C3%BAtbol">Federación Puertorriqueña de Fútbol</a> and a Senior National Team which is ranked 106 by <a href="FIFA">FIFA</a>. <a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a> has only made it as far as the second round or regional play for a <a href="World%20Cup%20Qualifier">World Cup Qualifier</a>, this was in 2008 when it beat <a href="Dominican%20Republic">Dominican Republic</a> 1-0 in the first round and lost against <a href="Honduras">Honduras</a> in the second round with an aggregate score of 6-2.
<a href="Puerto%20Rico">Puerto Rico</a> currently has a professional league called the <a href="Puerto%20Rico%20Soccer%20League">Puerto Rico Soccer League</a> which was founded in 2008 and is composed of 8 teams. It also had the <a href="Puerto%20Rico%20Islanders">Puerto Rico Islanders</a>, which played in the <a href="North%20American%20Soccer%20League%20%282010%29">North American Soccer League</a>, the second tier of the <a href="American%20Soccer%20Pyramid">American Soccer Pyramid</a>. The team has been defunct since 2012; however, in June 2015 a new NASL team, <a href="Puerto%20Rico%20FC">Puerto Rico FC</a>, was announced.
In 2017, <a href="Puerto%20Rico%20Sol">Puerto Rico Sol</a> became the first women's pro soccer club in the Caribbean.
The following are among the players who have played for Puerto Rico: <a href="H%C3%A9ctor%20Ramos">Héctor Ramos</a>, <a href="Alexis%20Rivera%20Curet">Alexis Rivera Curet</a>, <a href="Andr%C3%A9s%20Cabrero">Andrés Cabrero</a>. There are several other Puerto Rican players or players of Puerto Rican descent playing abroad in foreign leagues.
Softball.
Women's softball has enjoyed certain popularity in Puerto Rico. The women's national softball team has won many international events and participated at many Olympics.
<a href="Lisa%20Fernandez">Lisa Fernandez</a> has represented the United States as member of the U.S. Women's Olympic Softball Team, winning gold medals in the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta, Georgia, 2000 Olympics in Sydney, Australia and in the 2004 Olympics in Athens, Greece. She established a women's softball record when she struck out 25 members of the women's Australian Olympic Softball Team. <a href="Ivelisse%20Echevarr%C3%ADa">Ivelisse Echevarría</a> who in 2003 was inducted into the International Softball Federation Hall of Fame is also considered by many to be the greatest pitcher born in Puerto Rico. Ten Puerto Ricans have been inducted into the International Softball Federation Hall of Fame so far.
The ten Puerto Ricans in International Softball Federation Hall of Fame are: Juan Pachot, Carlos Velasquez Class of 1997; Ismael "Chavalillo" Delgado, Jorge Tanco, <a href="Alejandro%20Cruz%20%28politician%29">Alejandro "Junior" Cruz</a> Class of 1993 and Ivelisse Echevarria, Betty Segarra, Clara Vazquez, Jose "Tuto" Agosto, Rafi Serrano Class of 2003.
Swimming (competitive).
<a href="Jesse%20Vassallo">Jesus "Jesse" Vassallo</a> is considered by many to be the greatest swimmer to have been born in Puerto Rico. In 1997, he became the first and so far the only Puerto Rican to be inducted into the <a href="International%20Swimming%20Hall%20of%20Fame">International Swimming Hall of Fame</a>. He currently heads the Puerto Rico Swimming Federation.
In 1966, 17-year-old <a href="Anita%20Lallande">Anita Lallande</a> set a new record in the Central American and Caribbean Games celebrated in San Juan, when she won a total of 10 gold medals.
<a href="Fernando%20Ca%C3%B1ales">Fernando Cañales</a> was a 100-meter freestyle finalist in the 1978 Berlin World Championships, earning a 5th place. He was the "first" Puerto Rican swimmer to final in the World Championships. He earned 5 gold medals and 1 silver medal during the 1978 Central American Championships in <a href="Medell%C3%ADn">Medellín</a>, <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a>. He became the first Puerto Rican to medal in the <a href="Pan%20American%20Games">Pan American Games</a> by winning silver in the 100 meters free in 1979 (San Juan, Puerto Rico) and repeating that feat in 1983 (Caracas, Venezuela).
<a href="Maritza%20Correia">Maritza Correia</a>, is the first black Puerto Rican woman in history to make the U.S. Olympic Swimming Team. She earned a silver medal swimming prelims of the 400m free relay at the <a href="2004%20Olympic%20Games">2004 Olympic Games</a> celebrated in <a href="Athens">Athens</a>, Greece.
Years after the demolition of the Escambrón Swimming Complex, San Juan Mayor <a href="Jorge%20Santini">Jorge Santini</a> opened the new roofed <a href="San%20Juan%20Natatorium">San Juan Natatorium</a>, developed by San Juan Sports Director <a href="Mar%C3%ADa%20Elena%20Batista">María Elena Batista</a>, herself a former Olympic Swimmer. The official opening of the San Juan Natatorium was December 15, 2006. A second natatorium was scheduled to open in time for the 2010 Central American and Caribbean Games in Mayagüez.
On May 19, 2012, <a href="Orlando%20Fern%C3%A1ndez">Orlando Fernández</a>, also known as "The Puerto Rican <a href="Aquaman">Aquaman</a>", became the first Puerto Rican to swim across the <a href="Strait%20of%20Gibraltar">Strait of Gibraltar</a>.
Tennis.
Tennis is not very popular as a fan sport in Puerto Rico, but many Puerto Ricans practice it as a means of exercise. The 1984 television match between <a href="Martina%20Navratilova">Martina Navratilova</a> and <a href="Gigi%20Fern%C3%A1ndez">Gigi Fernández</a> was one of the most watched events of the year in Puerto Rican television. Gigi Fernández is arguably Puerto Rico's most famous tennis player ever, having won doubles championships in Grand Slam tournaments, including <a href="Wimbledon%20championships">Wimbledon</a>, winning gold medals for the USA doubles team in the 1992 and 1996 Olympics, being ranked no. 1 in the world for women's doubles tournaments, and being ranked among the top 30 singles players for most of her career. She is widely considered to be one of the greatest doubles players of all time.
<a href="Kristina%20Brandi">Kristina Brandi</a> is the first Puerto Rican tennis player to win an <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic</a> tennis match representing Puerto Rico. Brandi represented Puerto Rico in the <a href="2004%20Olympics">2004 Olympics</a>, where she beat <a href="Jelena%20Kostani%C4%87">Jelena Kostanić</a> from <a href="Croatia">Croatia</a> (7-5 and 6-1).
<a href="Charlie%20Pasarell">Charlie Pasarell</a> was another noted Puerto Rican Tennis player. He lost to <a href="Pancho%20Gonzalez">Pancho Gonzalez</a> in 1969, in the second longest singles match by number of games before the introduction of the tiebreaker. It took Pancho Gonzales 112 games to defeat Charlie Pasarell in the first round 22–24, 1–6, 16–14, 6–3, 11–9.
Rafael Jordan was a player that many considered had potential to become a men's professional tour champion, but he died after an automobile accident during the mid-1990s.
<a href="Monica%20Puig">Monica Puig</a> became the first person to win an Olympic Gold Medal for Puerto Rico at the <a href="2016%20Summer%20Olympics">2016 Summer Olympics</a>. She defeated Germany's Angelique Kerber in the women's singles tennis final.
Track and field.
Track and Field, also known as athletics, has been another noteworthy sport in Puerto Rico, with Puerto Rican runners, hurlers and throwers have participated at the <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic</a> and <a href="Paralympic%20Games">Paralympic Games</a> with two and five medals, respectively, as of 2021. Most schools base their field days only on track and field events. <a href="Enrique%20Laguerre">Enrique Laguerre</a> held it in high regard for its nature as a "fair [or loyal] competitition". It is taken to be one of the sports that should be considered outside of the traditional baseball, volleyball and basketball offerings, for children with <a href="attention%20deficit%20hyperactivity%20disorder">attention deficit hyperactivity disorder</a>, as "the child manages to function better in sports where the emphasis is on improving their own performance". Famous Puerto Rican track and fielders include <a href="Rebekah%20Colberg">Rebekah Colberg</a> and <a href="Angelita%20Lind">Angelita Lind</a>.
Juan Juarbe Juarbe, who would later serve as <a href="Pedro%20Albizu%20Campos">Pedro Albizu Campos'</a> personal secretary, was the first Puerto Rican to participate in any international sporting event, competing in the <a href="1930%20Central%20American%20and%20Caribbean%20Games">1930 Central American and Caribbean Games</a>, and the first to win a gold medal at an international track and field competition.
<a href="Rebekah%20Colberg">Rebekah Colberg</a>, considered the "Mother of Women's Sports in Puerto Rico", was the Puerto Rico tennis champion for fourteen consecutive years, from 1932 till 1946. In 1938, she won two <a href="gold%20medal">gold medal</a>s at the IV <a href="Central%20American%20and%20Caribbean%20Games">Central American and Caribbean Games</a>, celebrated in <a href="Panama">Panama</a>, in the <a href="discus">discus</a> and <a href="Javelin%20throw">javelin</a> events. In 1946, when the games were celebrated in Mexico, she won a gold medal in <a href="softball">softball</a>. While studying for her master's degree at Columbia University, she was in the university's <a href="field%20hockey">field hockey</a> and <a href="lacrosse">lacrosse</a> championship teams. She was also a member of the undefeated women's <a href="basketball">basketball</a> team of the University of Mexico.
Even though <a href="Juan%20%26quot%3BPapo%26quot%3B%20Franceschi">Juan "Papo" Franceschi</a> had been a drug addict at one point in his life, he set several national records on the track and had a street named after him is nis native <a href="San%20Ant%C3%B3n">San Antón, Ponce</a>. However, his name is not part of the <a href="Museo%20Francisco%20%26quot%3BPancho%26quot%3B%20Coimbre">Francisco "Pancho" Coimbre sports museum</a>.
Heriberto Cruz Mejil, who as a kid, lacking access to a running track, used to run from the <a href="Gu%C3%A1nica%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">Guánica</a> pier to the Caña Gorda baths. He went on to win silver and gold at the 110 metre hurdle event in the in the <a href="1962%20Central%20American%20and%20Caribbean%20Games">1962 Kingston</a> and <a href="1966%20Central%20American%20and%20Caribbean%20Games">1966 San Juan Central American Caribbean Games</a>, respectively, beating the then-fourth best runner in the world <a href="V%C3%ADctor%20Maldonado">Víctor Maldonado</a> in the latter. After which, he retired at age 27. Additionally, he was a <a href="Liga%20Atl%C3%A9tica%20Interuniversitaria%20de%20Puerto%20Rico">LAI</a> champion three consecutive years, competing at the <a href="Las%20Justas">"Justas"</a> 110 metre hurdle, high jump and 4 x 400 metre relay events. Both his hometown's track and a tournament bear his name.
Professional baseball player <a href="Roberto%20Clemente">Roberto Clemente</a> was Julio Vizcarrondo Coronado high school's most valuable player for three consecutive years, and was described as "excellent in the sport of track and field." While Julio “Buyín” Camacho Mattei, who is better known for his professional volleball career, also competed in track and field events, among other sports. Eduardo Hernández, who played for the Adjuntas Giants baseball team, was part of the <a href="Colegio%20Ponce%C3%B1o">Colegio Ponceño's</a> track and field team.
<a href="Angelita%20Lind">Angelita Lind</a>, often called the "Angel of Puerto Rico", has represented the island and participated in three <a href="Central%20American%20and%20Caribbean%20Games">Central American and Caribbean Games</a> (CAC) and won two <a href="gold%20medal">gold medal</a>s, three <a href="silver%20medal">silver medal</a>s and one <a href="bronze%20medal">bronze medal</a>. She also participated in three <a href="Pan%20American%20Games">Pan American Games</a> and in the <a href="1984%20Summer%20Olympics">1984 Olympics</a> celebrated in <a href="Los%20Angeles%2C%20California">Los Angeles, California</a>.
The <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%202010%20Central%20American%20and%20Caribbean%20Games">2010 Central American and Caribbean Games athletics competitions</a> were held at the <a href="Mayag%C3%BCez%20Athletics%20Stadium">Mayagüez Athletics Stadium</a>.
Puerto Rican athletes participated in the <a href="2011%20Special%20Olympics%20World%20Summer%20Games">2011 Special Olympics World Summer Games</a>, competing in the 12, 50, 100, 200, 400, 800 and 1,500 metres, as well as relay and shot put.
A survey in 2011 found that 75% of Puerto Rican university student athletes that attended private institutions of higher learning partake in this discipline.
Eight of the 23 athletes competing at the <a href="2012%20Summer%20Olympics">2012 London Olympics</a>, were track and field: <a href="Jamele%20Mason">Jamele Mason</a> (400 metre hurdles), <a href="Eric%20Alejandro">Eric Alejandro</a> (400 metre hurdles), <a href="Beverly%20Ramos">Beverly Ramos</a> (3000 metre steeplechase), <a href="Enrique%20Llanos">Enrique Llanos</a> (110 metre hurdles), <a href="H%C3%A9ctor%20Cotto">Héctor Cotto</a> (110 metre hurdles), <a href="Miguel%20L%C3%B3pez%20%28athlete%29">Miguel López</a> (100 metre), <a href="Wesley%20V%C3%A1zquez">Wesley Vázquez</a> (800 metre) and <a href="Samuel%20V%C3%A1zquez">Samuel Vázquez</a> (1500 metros). Additionally, <a href="Javier%20Culson">Javier Culson</a>, who had become the first Puerto Rican track and field artist to be a flagbearer since the <a href="1948%20Summer%20Olympics">1948 London Olympics</a>, made history by becoming the first Puerto Rican track and field runner in an Olympic Game, to win the bronze medal at the 2012 London Olympics. He won it in the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%202012%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20400%20metres%20hurdles">400 metre hurdle competition</a>. 
The <a href="Puerto%20Rico%20Department%20of%20Education">Department of Education</a> has pushed for field day events to not be limited to track and field since 2015, arguing that "it must allow the participation of all students regardless of differences and interests."
In 2019, 16 track and field athletes competed in the <a href="2019%20Pan%20American%20Games">Lima Pan American Games</a>, of which 12 achieved minimum marks to qualify.
Puerto Rico governor <a href="Pedro%20Pierluisi">Pedro Pierluisi</a> named retired long jumper and the <a href="University%20of%20Puerto%20Rico%20at%20Mayag%C3%BCez">University of Puerto Rico at Mayagüez's</a> Sport Affairs Director and lead coach <a href="Ray%20Qui%C3%B1ones">Ray J. Quiñones Vázquez</a> as <a href="Secretary%20of%20Sports%20and%20Recreation%20of%20Puerto%20Rico">Secretary of Sports and Recreation of Puerto Rico</a>.
The first event held at the <a href="Carolina%2C%20Puerto%20Rico%23Sports">Basilio Rodríguez Cruz Athletic Track</a>, <a href="Carolina%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">Carolina's</a> running track, after its million-dollar recontrsuction after hurricanes <a href="Hurricane%20Irma">Irma</a> and <a href="Hurricane%20Maria">María</a> was the XV Spring Athletics Classic ("Clásico Primaveral de Atletismo") a March 2021 Olympic and Paralympic qualafying event. 
A change in the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%202020%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Qualification">qualifications for the athletic events at the 2020 Olympics</a> by <a href="World%20Athletics">World Athletics</a>, the sport's international federation, making the <a href="Qualifying%20standards%20in%20athletics">first criteria to qualify time or minimum marks, and the second ranking</a>, was met with criticism in Puerto Rico. As most ranking events are held in Europe, making it less accessible from athletes from other continents. The ranking criterion is used to fill up vacant spaces. However, all four athletes whom met minimum marks, <a href="Jasmine%20Camacho-Quinn">Jasmine Camacho-Quinn</a> and <a href="Wesley%20V%C3%A1zquez">Wesley Vázquez</a>, <a href="Ryan%20S%C3%A1nchez">Ryan Sánchez</a> (the only debut in the quartet) and <a href="Andr%C3%A9s%20Arroyo">Andrés Arroyo</a>, were all eventually chosen and partook in the subsequent Olympics, arriving on 25 July to the <a href="Olympic%20Village">Olympic Village</a>. The latter three all competed in the same event, making it the first time that Puerto Rico had three atheltes competing at the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%202020%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20800%20metres">800 metre event</a>. Nevertheless, other athletes, such as Rachelle de Orbeta, <a href="Luis%20Castro%20%28athlete%29">Luis Joel Castro</a>, <a href="Grace%20Claxton">Grace Claxton</a> and Ayden Owens failed to enter based on missing the ranking cutoff.
<a href="Jasmine%20Camacho-Quinn">Jasmine Camacho-Quinn</a>, who had debuted at the <a href="2016%20Summer%20Olympics">2016 Rio Games</a>, competed in the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%202020%20Summer%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20100%20metres%20hurdles">100 metre hurdle at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics</a>, winning gold and setting an <a href="List%20of%20Olympic%20records%20in%20athletics">Olympic record</a>, becoming the first Puerto rican to ever do so and the second Puerto Rican ever to win a gold medal while <a href="Puerto%20Rico%20at%20the%20Olympics">representing Puerto Rico</a>. At 12.26 seconds, her personal best, she tied for the <a href="100%20metres%20hurdles%23All-time%20top%2025">fourth fastest time in history</a>. By winning the gold, she climbed to the top spot of the <a href="World%20Athletics%20Rankings">World Athletics Rankings</a> in her event. 
During the <a href="2020%20Summer%20Paralympics%20opening%20ceremony">2020 Summer Paralympics opening ceremony</a>, both <a href="2020%20Summer%20Paralympics%20Parade%20of%20Nations">flagbearers</a> of Puerto Rico's delegation, Yaimillie Díaz Colón and Carmelo Rivera Fuentes, who competed in the amputee and intellectual disabilities <a href="Para-athletics%20classification">classifications</a>, respectively, were track and field athletes.
Volleyball.
The <a href="Puerto%20Rican%20Volleyball%20Federation">Puerto Rican Volleyball Federation</a> was founded in 1958, the first men's tournament organized was the 'Torneo Preolimpico'. The federation's first president was <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Lu%C3%ADs%20Purcell%20Rodr%C3%ADguez">Jose L. Purcell</a>. Ten years later the <a href="Liga%20de%20Voleibol%20Superior%20Femenino">Women's League</a> was established.
Long considered the dormant sport among major sports in Puerto Rico, Volleyball has enjoyed much popularity since the 1990s, both in its professional and beach volleyball versions. Puerto Rico's "Liga Superior de Voleibol" has thrived in recent years, both in the <a href="Liga%20de%20Voleibol%20Superior%20Masculino">men's</a> and <a href="Liga%20de%20Voleibol%20Superior%20Femenino">women's</a> tournaments.
In 1970, most of Puerto Rico's national women's volleyball team's members were killed <a href="Dominicana%20DC-9%20air%20disaster">when a plane that was flying them to San Juan, Puerto Rico from the Dominican Republic crashed shortly after take-off</a>.
In 1997, debut of foreign player in <a href="Liga%20de%20Voleibol%20Superior%20Femenino">Women League</a>. The most dominated are Laura Salinas from Monterrey, Mexico, lead the <a href="Mexico%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Mexico national team</a> to several international competition. The foreign player debut in Women's League in 2000.
Some of Puerto Rico's famous volleyball players are Willie De Jesus, <a href="Ra%C3%BAl%20Papaleo">Raúl Papaleo</a> and <a href="H%C3%A9ctor%20Soto">Héctor Soto</a>. Papaleo and <a href="Ram%C3%B3n%20Hern%C3%A1ndez%20%28beach%20volleyball%29">Ramón 'Monchito' Hernández</a> participated in 2004 Olympic Games in Athens in Beach Volleyball, first ever volleyball team in the Island Olympic history. <a href="Laura%20Daniela%20Lloreda">Laura Daniela Lloreda</a>, meanwhile, is a Puerto Rican who played in Mexico's national volleyball team.
<a href="H%C3%A9ctor%20Soto">Héctor "Picky" Soto</a> is the first Latin American player that has led the scoring in the World Championship's history. Soto won the Best Scorer award in 2006 FIVB World Championship in Japan and 2007 FIVB World Cup in Japan. During the World Cup, he scored 43 point against Korea, in the process establishing a scoring record. Outside of his international performance, Soto has played in the professional leagues of Italy, Tunisia, Japan and Russia.
Lacrosse.
For the first time, Puerto Rico will feature a national team at the 2022 <a href="Under-19%20World%20Lacrosse%20Championships">Under-19 World Lacrosse Championships</a>.
